message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of edema and decreased urine output and the kidney biopsy findings of crescent-shaped glomeruli suggest rapidly progressive or crescentic glomerulonephritis. The immunofluorescent microscopy is most likely to show no deposits, as this type of glomerulonephritis is typically caused by antiglomerular basement membrane antibodies, resulting in fibrinoid necrosis of the glomerular capillaries without immune complex deposition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of crescent-shaped glomeruli suggests rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Immunofluorescent microscopy of the tissue sample is most likely to show no deposits, as this is a feature of pauci-immune glomerulonephritis. Subendothelial deposits are found in conditions such as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, mesangial deposits in IgA nephropathy, and subepithelial deposits in membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Crescent-shaped glomeruli suggest rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Immunofluorescence microscopy can help identify deposits in the glomeruli, but since there is no mention of any specific deposit in the question, the answer is (D) No deposits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and kidney biopsy findings are consistent with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which is most commonly associated with ANCA-associated vasculitis. Immunofluorescent microscopy may show no deposits or only small amounts of IgG and complement in a granular pattern, as this type of glomerulonephritis is caused by immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane, rather than deposits in specific locations. Options A-C are associated with other types of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Crescent-shaped glomeruli are most commonly associated with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and in this case, there are no indications of any immune deposits, so the answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the presence of crescent-shaped glomeruli on kidney biopsy indicate rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Immunofluorescent microscopy may show different types of deposits depending on the underlying cause, but it is also possible for there to be no deposits present. Therefore, (D) is the most likely answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and kidney biopsy findings suggest rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Immunofluorescent microscopy of the tissue sample in RPGN typically shows no immune deposits. Subendothelial deposits are seen in membranous nephropathy, mesangial deposits are seen in IgA nephropathy, and subepithelial deposits are seen in membranous nephropathy and some cases of lupus nephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and biopsy findings suggest rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). RPGN is not associated with immune complex deposition, so the most likely finding on immunofluorescent microscopy is no deposits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of crescent-shaped glomeruli suggests rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and the absence of any deposit suggests pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, which is most commonly associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Immunofluorescence would typically show a negative result or a very weak staining of IgG and C3.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) and the crescent-shaped glomeruli in the kidney biopsy confirm the diagnosis. Immunofluorescent microscopy usually does not show deposits in cases of RPGN, therefore the answer is (D). Subendothelial deposits are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, mesangial deposits are seen in IgA nephropathy, and subepithelial deposits are seen in membranous nephropathy.
